meta_questions.text: Where is the business located (country, state, city)?
meta_questions.info: Write the country, state or province if applicable, and the city where the business mainly operates. If there are multiple locations, list them all. Example: USA, North Carolina, Charlotte.

meta_questions.text: What is the primary industry or activity of the business?
meta_questions.hint: Describe in simple words what the business does.
meta_questions.info: Describe in simple words what the business does, such as coffee shop, plumbing services, online clothing store, small factory. If there are several activities, pick the one that brings the most revenue.

meta_questions.hint: Pick a rough yearly sales range.
meta_questions.info: Pick the rough yearly sales before expenses. If you do not know the exact number, choose the closest range. Ask the seller for last year sales totals or tax filings if needed.

meta_questions.text: How many people work in the business (FTE including owner)?
meta_questions.info: Count everyone who works regularly. Two half time workers are about one full time equivalent. Include the owner if they work in the business.

meta_questions.text: Do you sell to government or state-owned customers?
meta_questions.info: Choose Yes if any customer is a government office, public agency, or state owned enterprise. This affects approvals and compliance checks.

meta_questions.text: Do you process personal or financial customer data (PII)?
meta_questions.info: If the business stores names, emails, phone numbers, or health or financial details, choose the level. None means almost no personal data. Limited means basic contacts or payments. High means sensitive data such as health or finance.
Internal field. The system sets a country or region risk factor from public indices to adjust scoring. You do not need to answer this.

questions.text: Owner’s weekly hours in day-to-day operations (approx)?
questions.info: High hours may mean the business depends too much on the owner.
questions.prompt_add: Good: ≤10–30h with delegation (SG27) and survivability (SG28). Red: >30h plus many owner-only tasks.

questions.text: Core systems (accounting/CRM/website/email): are admin access and regular backups documented and transferable?
questions.info: Ask for a list of systems with admin logins, who controls them, and how backups are done. Ensure handover.
questions.prompt_add: Good: all documented & transferable. Red: not documented; penalize if digital assets also problematic (SG35).

questions.text: Any loans, leases, or liens on assets included in the sale?
questions.info: Liens/encumbrances mean a lender has rights over equipment or vehicles. Confirm clearance at or before closing.
questions.prompt_add: Good: no encumbrances or clear payoff plan. Red: encumbered critical assets plus downtime (SG25) or no service (SG24).

questions.text: Is a pilot or test-drive (temporary management/lease 30+ days) possible before closing?
questions.info: A pilot lets you run the business briefly to test operations and customers before you fully commit.
questions.prompt_add: Good: pilot allowed. Red: refuses pilot where transfer/licensing risk exists (SG20/SG21).

questions.text: Did bad-debt write-offs in the last 12 months exceed ~1% of revenue?
questions.info: Bad debt means invoices you will never collect. High write-offs can mean weak customer quality.
questions.prompt_add: Good: ≤1% write-offs with reasonable DSO. Red: high write-offs and long DSO; check mismatch if DSO long but write-offs claimed low.

questions.text: Any critical supplier >40% of purchases? Is an equal alternative available?
questions.info: If one supplier is critical and there’s no backup, risk is high.
questions.prompt_add: Good: diversified or viable alternative. Red: concentrated with no alternative; penalize unknown if inventory issues exist (SG23).

questions.text: Average time to collect receivables (DSO)
questions.info: How many days on average it takes customers to pay invoices. Long delays can cause cash problems.
questions.prompt_add: Good: DSO aligned with industry norms; <45 days for most SMB B2B. Red: >45 without explanation or with low write-offs (SG15) inconsistency.

questions.text: Premises: owned or leased? If leased, how much time remains?
questions.info: Short time left may force a move or tough renegotiation.
questions.prompt_add: Good: owned or ≥2y lease. Red: <2y and weak landlord stance (SG20), esp. with backlog exposure (SG13).

questions.text: Do all digital assets (domains/website/email/social/ad accounts) belong to the business and transfer to the buyer?
questions.info: List domains, hosting, email admin, social and ad accounts. Ensure ownership and transferability.
questions.prompt_add: Good: all transfer. Red: major gaps; penalize mismatch if SG29 claims documentation but assets not transferable.

questions.text: Which tasks are owner-only (e.g., pricing, sales, key clients)?
questions.info: Owner-only tasks increase risk for a new buyer.
questions.prompt_add: Good: none/some with cover. Red: many owner-only tasks, esp. if SG26 is high hours.

questions.text: For key equipment, are service/maintenance contracts in place?
questions.info: Service contracts help avoid long breakdowns.
questions.prompt_add: Good: full coverage, low downtime. Red: none plus downtime (SG25) and encumbrances (SG18).

questions.text: Inventory issues more often: long aging >90 days or frequent stockouts?
questions.info: Aging ties up cash; stockouts lose sales.
questions.prompt_add: Good: balanced/controlled. Red: chronic aging or stockouts; weigh with supplier concentration (SG22) and seasonality (SG06).

questions.text: Does seasonality require extra working capital at peaks?
questions.info: Working capital is cash tied in inventory and unpaid invoices. Seasonal businesses may need extra cash or short-term loans.
questions.prompt_add: Good: no exceptional WC strain or well-planned financing. Red: heavy seasonal WC strain without plan; weigh with SG23 (inventory) and SG04.

questions.text: Is the lease transferable to a new owner? Does the landlord agree in principle?
questions.info: Some leases need landlord approval when ownership changes. Ask for a simple confirmation email if possible.
questions.prompt_add: Good: transferable with consent. Red: no/unknown without protections (SG33) or pilot (SG34).

questions.text: Is the seller willing to provide a paid transition (e.g., 60 hours over 2 months) and personal introductions to key clients?
questions.info: Transition support reduces risk.
questions.prompt_add: Good: structured support & intros, esp. with client concentration (SG09/SG10). Red: no support while owner-dependency is high.

questions.text: In the last year, did you use unusually deep discounts to keep sales?
questions.info: Frequent heavy discounts can mean pressure from competitors or weak demand.
questions.prompt_add: Good: rare/no discounting with healthy margins (SG07). Red: frequent deep discounting, esp. if margins low or revenue flat/down.

questions.text: How long has the current revenue model existed?
questions.info: If the revenue model changed recently, risk is higher until it proves stable.
questions.prompt_add: Good: model 3–7y+. Red: <1y without strong backlog or margins; penalize volatility per SG04/SG05.

questions.text: Any salary or mandatory payment delays to employees in last 12 months?
questions.info: Delays are a sign of cash stress and can cause legal issues.
questions.prompt_add: Good: no delays. Red: delays, especially with revenue down (SG04) or tax arrears (SG16).

questions.text: Have there been serious buyers in the last 6 months?
questions.hint: LOI or DD access counts as serious.
questions.info: Serious buyers usually sign a letter of intent or receive access to key documents. Ask if anyone reached that stage and why a deal did not close.
questions.prompt_add: Good: fresh listing or LOI/DD activity with credible reasons. Red: long time on market without serious interest or multiple withdrawn deals without clear cause. Cross-check SG01 (motive) and SG04 (trend).

questions.text: How old is the business?
questions.info: Age shows stability and track record.
questions.prompt_add: Good: 5–20 years with consistent ops. Red: <2 years (unproven) unless strong backlog/margins. Adjust tolerance by MET.IND.

questions.text: Largest single customer's share of revenue (approx)?
questions.info: Ask for a simple top-customer list. High share is risk if they leave.
questions.prompt_add: Good: <20% for most sizes; tolerate higher for micro (MET.SIZE). Red: >35% with weak transferability (SG11) or no seller support (SG32).

questions.text: Are there any overdue taxes/penalties or tax installment plans now?
questions.info: Ask if taxes are fully paid. Overdue taxes or payment plans mean extra risk.
questions.prompt_add: Good: no arrears. Red: current arrears or installment plans; amplify if revenue is down (SG04).

questions.text: Why are you selling now?
questions.hint: Select up to two reasons (rank them).
questions.info: We want to know if the sale is planned (retirement, moving) or forced (falling sales, lawsuits, urgent cash needs). Ask the seller directly.
questions.prompt_add: Score intent of sale. Good: planned retirement/move/strategic refocus. Red: urgent cash need, lawsuits/tax issues, sale due to heavy losses. Penalize contradictions with SG02/SG04. Bands: 0–19 critical; 20–49 high; 50–79 moderate; 80–100 low.

questions.text: Typical gross margin band across main products/services
questions.info: Gross margin equals sales minus direct costs divided by sales. If margins are low, small price cuts can hurt.
questions.prompt_add: Good: 20–40%+ stable. Red: <20% with discounting (SG08) or price pressure. Consider MET.IND norms.

questions.text: Active insurance policies (general/professional/workers/cyber)? Any claims in last 3 years?
questions.info: Insurance helps with accidents and disputes.
questions.prompt_add: Good: coverage in place; occasional claims ok. Red: no coverage or many claims linked to open issues (SG30).

questions.text: Do key customer contracts allow transfer on change of control?
questions.hint: Will contracts survive the ownership change?
questions.info: Some contracts stop or need approval when the owner changes. If not transferable, sales may drop after you buy.
questions.prompt_add: Good: all transferable. Red: non-transferable or unknown without protections (SG33) and high concentration (SG09/SG10).

questions.text: Are you open to escrow/conditional payment or reversal if key approvals are not obtained?
questions.info: Escrow/conditional payment means you hold part of the price until approvals happen (like landlord consent). Reversal means you can undo the deal if approvals fail.
questions.prompt_add: Good: escrow/conditional/reversal accepted. Red: refuses protections while transfer risks exist (SG11/SG20/SG21).

questions.text: Any regulatory, environmental, health/safety, or sanitation violations in last 3 years?
questions.info: Ask about inspections or notices from authorities. If there were problems, were they fixed? Are any cases still open?
questions.prompt_add: Good: none or closed. Red: open violations, especially if licenses are problematic (SG21).

questions.text: Can the business run for 2+ months without the current owner?
questions.info: If not, say what would stop.
questions.prompt_add: Good: yes, with processes and team. Red: no, esp. with many owner-only tasks (SG27) and high hours (SG26).

questions.text: Any unplanned downtime of critical equipment >2 days in last 12 months?
questions.info: If yes, note why and how it was fixed.
questions.prompt_add: Good: no outages or well-managed rare incident. Red: repeated or long outages with poor service cover (SG24).

questions.text: Any months in the last year with >30% drop vs same month last year?
questions.info: A single very bad month can signal a lost client or a supply issue. Ask to see monthly sales for two years.
questions.prompt_add: Good: no large dips or dips explained by seasonality. Red: unexplained dips conflicting with SG04 trend.

questions.text: Top-5 customers combined share of revenue (approx)?
questions.info: If this number is high, losing one hurts a lot.
questions.prompt_add: Good: diversified <40–60% depending on size. Red: >60% with weak contracts (SG11).

questions.text: Any lawsuits, regulatory fines, or investigations in the last 3 years? Any open now?
questions.info: Ask if there were any legal or government issues. If yes, were they closed or still open?
questions.prompt_add: Good: none or closed minor items. Red: open cases; penalize if inconsistent with claimed stability (SG04 up/flat and SG13 ≥3m).

questions.text: Are required licenses/permits valid and transferable to the buyer?
questions.info: Some businesses need health, safety, or other permits. If they cannot transfer, operations may pause.
questions.prompt_add: Good: all valid & transferable. Red: major issues or unknown without protections (SG33/SG34).

questions.text: Does current backlog/subscriptions cover at least the next 3 months of revenue?
questions.info: Ask how long current orders/subscriptions last if no new sales happen.
questions.prompt_add: Good: ≥3 months coverage. Red: <3 months, esp. with revenue down (SG04) or recent churn (SG12).

questions.text: Last 12 months revenue compared to the previous 12 months
questions.info: Compare sales for the last full year to the year before. Ask the seller for annual totals or tax returns.
questions.prompt_add: Good: up/flat with plausible context. Red: down ≥20% without credible reason or conflicting with SG05/SG12/SG13. Weigh industry cyclicality (MET.IND).

questions.text: In the last 12 months, did you lose clients totaling >10% of revenue?
questions.info: If yes, ask why (competition, service, price).
questions.prompt_add: Good: no material churn or replaced quickly. Red: >10% churn conflicting with SG04 up/flat or SG13 ≥3m.

optional_questions.text: Do you use sales agents (>20% of sales) or sell to government/state-owned entities?
optional_questions.hint: Third parties or public sector sales.
optional_questions.info: Agents and government sales often require extra rules and checks.
optional_questions.prompt_add: Higher inherent risk with agents/public sales; weigh need for ABC controls (SGA02/SGA03) and deal protections (SG33). Scale by MET.RISKCTX.

optional_questions.text: Do you have an anti-bribery policy and a whistleblowing channel?
optional_questions.info: Policy says no bribes; whistleblowing is a safe reporting line.
optional_questions.prompt_add: Good: both present. Red: none/unknown in higher-risk context (MET.RISKCTX).

optional_questions.text: Are commissions to agents/intermediaries over 10% on any deals in the last 12 months?
optional_questions.info: Very high commissions may be a red flag; ask why.
optional_questions.prompt_add: Good: normal commissions. Red: >10% without justification; scale by MET.RISKCTX.

optional_questions.text: Are “expedite/facilitation” payments used for licenses or customs?
optional_questions.hint: Small payments to speed routine tasks.
optional_questions.info: In some places these are common but risky.
optional_questions.prompt_add: Good: none/rare. Red: often, esp. alongside license issues (SG21) or supplier choke points (SG22); scale by MET.RISKCTX.

optional_questions.text: Any investigations or claims about bribery/improper payments in the last 3 years?
optional_questions.info: If cases exist, were they closed?
optional_questions.prompt_add: Good: none or past closed with remediation. Red: open now; scale by MET.RISKCTX.

optional_questions.text: Do you check key customers/suppliers against sanctions/PEP lists (KYC)?
optional_questions.info: KYC reduces risk of restricted or politically exposed parties.
optional_questions.prompt_add: Good: risk-based checks. Red: no/unknown with concentrated suppliers (SG22); scale by MET.RISKCTX.
